docs.lead_paragraph: Behaviors that we do not understand often become nearly invisible -- even when, in retrospect, we see how truly strange they are. When I was a psychiatric resident, we had a faculty member who was famous for his messy office: stacks of papers and old journals covered every chair and table as well as much of the floor. One day, as I walked past the open office door with one of my supervisors, he murmured mildly, ''Odd duck.'' And that was as far as anyone seemed to reflect on this peculiar state of affairs within an institution staffed by psychiatrists. Eventually, the faculty member had to be given another office in which to see patients.

headline.main: Digging Up A Disorder From a Mess

docs.abstract: Dr Anna Fels comments on behaviors associated with psychiatric diagnosis of obsessive-compulsive personality disorder, an obscure cousin of more famous obsessive-compulsive disorder (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers are proposing a new entry to the list of tastes, like sweet and salty, that the tongue can discern. It's called fat. Dr. Richard Mattes, a professor of foods and nutrition at Purdue, questions the widespread belief that fat, despite its important role in some of the most popular and least healthful foods, has no inherent flavor.

headline.main: On the Tongue, Fat Passes Taste Test

docs.abstract: Researchers propose new entry to list of tastes, like sweet and salty, that tongue can discern--fat (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: It would not be like him to lie down and die quietly. Larry Kramer, the 66-year-old novelist and playwright, AIDS activist and agitator, is fighting again.

headline.main: H.I.V. Patients Get Fresh Hopes for Donor Organs

docs.abstract: Organ transplants for people with HIV offer new promise, where just few years ago such transplants were unthinkable; prognosis for people with HIV has improved markedly since 1996, when combination drug therapy came into widespread use; surgeons began trying transplants in people with HIV, and initial results suggest that they tolerate immune-suppressing drugs better than doctors had anticipated; as result, surgeons say it is not ethical to deny transplants to HIV patients; examples cited; photos (L)
docs.snippet: It would not be like him to lie down and die quietly.    Larry Kramer, the 66-year-old novelist and playwright, AIDS activist and agitator, is fighting again.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some people with H.I.V. turn to herbal medicines to supplement the mix of conventional drugs they take to keep their infections in check. But now a study has found that garlic supplements, among the most popular of the products, may pose a special risk. The supplement appears to reduce sharply the effectiveness of the drug saquinavir, researchers report in the current online issue of Clinical Infectious Diseases.

headline.main: Herbal Aid Saps Strength of H.I.V. Drug

docs.abstract: Study finds that garlic supplements, among most popular of herbal medicines taken by people with HIV, may pose special risk; supplement appears to reduce sharply the effectiveness of drug saquinavir (S)
docs.snippet: Some people with H.I.V. turn to herbal medicines to supplement the mix of conventional drugs they take to keep their infections in check.    But now a study has found that garlic supplements, among the most popular of the products, may pose a special...

docs.lead_paragraph: The sophisticated brain-scanning devices known as functional M.R.I.'s can sometimes be thrown off by something as simple as a few cups of coffee, a new study reports. The brain scans are largely used in research and on people who have suffered serious strokes, so the immediate implications for patient care are limited, the researchers said. But the implications may change as the M.R.I.'s become more widely used, they added.

headline.main: When Coffee Stains the Brain Scan

docs.abstract: Study reports that sophisticated brain-scanning devices known as functional MRI's can sometimes be thrown off by something as simple as few cups of coffee (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The obituaries all said that George Harrison died of cancer. But, in fact, what killed Mr. Harrison was smoking. Although public reports of his medical history are somewhat scanty, certain facts are clear. In 1997 he was treated for throat cancer, which he himself attributed to many years of smoking. He said at the time that he had quit smoking and that his doctors anticipated a complete cure.

headline.main: An Old Enemy, Smoking, Hangs Tough

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on persistence of smoking in society, noting 48 million Americans still smoke, despite well-known threats to life and health; notes lung cancer is leading cause of cancer deaths in men and women; photos of George Harrison, former Beatle who died of cancer, which he attributed to many years of smoking (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Young goalkeepers who play soccer with adult-size balls instead of smaller ones increase their risk of breaking their hands or wrists, a new study has found. A full-size ball weighs less than a pound, but its potential for causing injury increases because of its speed, which can reach as much as 50 miles an hour when kicked by a skilled adult. Even at slower speeds, the result can be the same as a bad fall, the researchers said.

headline.main: Soccer Found Safer With Smaller Balls

docs.abstract: Study finds that young goalkeepers who play soccer with adult-sized balls instead of smaller ones increase risk of breaking their hands or wrists; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1993, right out of college, Maura Donovan began to feel sick to her stomach periodically throughout the day. She had a burning sensation in her chest and cramps that were at their worst every morning after breakfast. Occasionally, when she went out for pizza and beer or Chinese food with friends, the pain got even worse. ''After a while,'' she said, ''I felt vaguely sick and sort of miserable all the time. People thought I was nuts.''

headline.main: As Acid Reflux Cases Rise, Doctors Are Asking Why

docs.abstract: Researchers say that incidence of cases of gastroesophageal reflux, technical name for what happens when digesting food and stomach acid pass up into esophagus through sphincter muscle at top of stomach, are rising; doctors do not fully understand what causes acid reflux; suggested causes of rising incidence include shifts in diet toward fattier foods, higher rates of obesity, and aggressive treatment of ulcers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A drug that doctors had hoped would benefit stroke patients does little good and may even make things worse, a new study reports. The drug, aptiganel hydrochloride, fared so poorly in clinical trials that the study was suspended to avoid possibly endangering the patients.

headline.main: Drug Proves Useless in Treating Strokes
